text: Same here! I have a master rate sheet with all of the prices spelled out and what they include, then I invoice a project rate each month as we go. Anything unique pops up, we address that. It does get very tricky balancing some work as hourly and some work as project rate, however.

elements.text: Same here! I have a master rate sheet with all of the prices spelled out and what they include, then I invoice a project rate each month as we go. Anything unique pops up, we address that. It does get very tricky balancing some work as hourly and some work as project rate, however.

text: What I'd do (borrowed heavily from years of proposals in the software development and consulting world) with MSA/SOW is put anything that will tend not to change in the former and anything that you'd want to be flexible on in the latter.  MSA for content, I'd say you want CYA language about contractor works for hire, content ownership, moral rights, invoicing terms (e.g. we pay net 60), jurisdiction and adjudication, etc.  This will tend to be a more "lawyer-y" document that staff counsel would create.  SOWs tend to be shorter and a bit less formal, and they'll be templated to where you fill in pay rate, timelines, milestones, etc.

SOWs tend to be shorter and a bit less formal, and they'll be templated to where you fill in pay rate, timelines, milestones, etc.

text: (SOW still probably created by staff counsel, but templated for you to fill out)
